facts.text: Station House Officer, Gharsiwa filed information in Court of Magistrate, First Class, Raipur against two appellants complaining that on March 10, 1962 they allowed three passengers to occupy front seat in public carrier and loaded goods in excess of sanctioned weight, committing offences under ss. 124 and 112 of Motor Vehicles Act 1939.
Magistrate issued process (summons) against appellants for appearance by pleader but did not make endorsement thereon in terms of s. 130(1)(b) of the Act.

Appellants submitted that summonses were not according to law and Magistrate's failure to endorse as per s. 130(1)(b) deprived them of right to intimate plea of guilty without appearing and remit sum not exceeding Rs. 25/- as specified.
Magistrate rejected appellants' plea and directed case to proceed further according to law.

Sessions Judge, Raipur in petition by appellants made reference to High Court of Madhya Pradesh recommending Magistrate's order be set aside as failure to comply with mandatory s. 130(1)(b) made proceedings unlawful.
High Court of Madhya Pradesh declined to accept the reference by judgment and order dated April 30, 1963 in Criminal Revision No. 24 of 1963.
Appellants preferred appeal to Supreme Court with certificate granted by High Court.
Offences under ss. 112, 124 not included in Part A of Fifth Schedule to Act.

legal_issues.text: Whether Magistrate taking cognizance of offence under ss. 112, 124 of Motor Vehicles Act was bound to endorse summons in terms of both cls. (a) and (b) of s. 130(1), and if failure to do so renders proceedings unlawful.
Nature of duty imposed by s. 130(1) on Court â€“ mandatory endorsement of both options or discretion to choose.

petitioner_arguments.text: Summonses not according to law; failure to endorse per s. 130(1)(b) deprived right to plead guilty by registered letter and remit <= Rs. 25/- without appearing.
Provision of s. 130(1) mandatory; failure to comply makes proceedings unlawful (as per Sessions Judge view).

respondent_arguments.text: s. 130(1) leaves option to Magistrate on consideration of materials to issue summons either per cl. (a) or cl. (b); not required to include both.
Accused can avail plea guilty option only if summons endorsed per cl. (b).

court_reasoning.text: s. 130(1) mandatory but requires summons stating options in cls. (a) or (b), not both; 'or' not to be converted into 'and'.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Nothing in sub-s. (1) indicates must endorse both clauses.

court_reasoning.text: Scheme of Act: s. 130 for minor offences (max penalty <= Rs. 25/-, not in Part A Fifth Schedule) to avoid harassment by allowing guilty plea and remit without appearance.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Not intended for serious offences to escape max penalty by paying <= Rs. 25/-.

court_reasoning.text: If both options mandatory, offender could avoid disqualification under s. 17 despite deserving it; inconsistent with Act for offences punishable with imprisonment not in Part A.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s. 130(3) bars further proceedings/disqualification if option availed.

court_reasoning.text: High Court view correct; Magistrate bound to issue summons per s. 130(1) but has option on clauses.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature did not intend compounding serious offences by fixed <= Rs. 25/- payment.

holdings.text: Magistrate not required to endorse summons with both cls. (a) and (b) of s. 130(1); failure to endorse cl. (b) does not render proceedings unlawful.
s. 130(1) imposes mandatory duty to issue summons stating one of the options (a) or (b), exercisable at Magistrate's discretion.

statutes_cited.name: Motor Vehicles Act, 1939
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences under ss. 112, 124; s. 130 procedure for summons and guilty plea option; s. 17 disqualification; Fifth Schedule Parts A, B classify offences.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court upheld High Court's order declining reference, holding that Magistrate was not bound to endorse both clauses of s. 130(1) on summons and proceedings not unlawful for omitting cl. (b).

key_quotes.text: "There can be no doubt on the plain terms of s. 130(1) that the provision is mandatory."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Acknowledges mandatory nature but clarifies scope.

key_quotes.text: "to hold that he is so commanded would be to convert the conjunction 'or' into 'and'."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Key to rejecting appellants' interpretation of s. 130(1).

key_quotes.text: Section 130 enacted "with a view to protect from harassment a person guilty of a minor infraction... by dispensing with his presence before the Magistrate."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains purpose, limiting to minor offences.
